content:
Here are a few different scenarios of Jinju's use in the village throughout the years, in cold and hot weather:

1. In the winter months, Jinju was used to carry hot water from the village's communal fireplace to the homes of the villagers. She was wrapped in layers of cloth to keep the water warm and to protect the villagers' hands from the heat. The villagers used the hot water to wash their hands and faces, and to make tea and other warm drinks to keep them cozy on cold days.
2. During the hot summer months, Jinju was used to carry cold water from the well to the homes of the villagers. She was placed in the shade to keep the water cool, and the villagers used her to quench their thirst and cool down on hot days.
3. On special occasions, Jinju was used to carry sake or other traditional Korean beverages to the village's communal gatherings. The villagers would fill Jinju with the drink of their choice and pass her around, taking turns sipping from her spout and enjoying each other's company.
4. On days when the villagers needed to wash their clothes, Jinju was used to carry hot water from the well to the village's communal washing area. The villagers would use Jinju to rinse and clean their clothes, and then hang them out to dry on the nearby clotheslines.
5. During the village's annual festivals, Jinju was used to carry water for the villagers to use to clean and purify themselves in preparation for the festivities. The villagers would fill Jinju with cold water from the well, and then use her to rinse their hands and faces before joining in the celebrations.
